thread.title: Clear message to LGBTQ conversion therapists: Stop it
thread.title_full: Clear message to LGBTQ conversion therapists: Stop it - Chicago Tribune

author: Heidi Stevens
title: Clear message to LGBTQ conversion therapists: Stop it
text:
Conversion therapies aimed at LGBTQ youth pose a serious health risk and should be ended immediately, according to a new report from the U.S. government.
"Mental health and behavioral interventions aimed at achieving a fixed outcome, such as gender conformity, including those aimed at changing gender identity or gender expression, are coercive, can be harmful and should not be part of treatment," reads the report, titled "Ending Conversion Therapy: Supporting and Affirming LGBTQ Youth."
(LGBTQ, in this report, stands for lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender or questioning.)
"Directing the child or adolescent to conform to any particular gender expression or identity, or directing parents and guardians to place pressure on the child or adolescent to conform to specific gender expressions and/or identities," the authors write, "is inappropriate and reinforces harmful gender stereotypes."
Released last week, the report is the work of a panel of psychiatrists, social workers and clinical psychologists convened by the American Psychological Association at the behest of President Barack Obama, who has publicly cited conversion therapy's "devastating effects."
"It's a huge deal for this to come from the White House," psychologist Joshua Wolff told me Monday. "To my knowledge, it's the first time a condemnation of this practice has come from the federal government."
Wolff, an assistant professor of psychology at Adler University in Chicago, served on the panel of APA-convened experts.
Conversion therapy has long been rejected by medical experts, and Illinois recently became the fourth state in the nation to ban its use on minors, joining California, New Jersey and Oregon. It's also illegal in Washington, D.C.
But it still happens. Leelah Alcorn , the transgender 17-year-old from Ohio who committed suicide in December, is one of the more public — and tragic — examples.
The goal of the report, Wolff said, is threefold.
"One is to inform further research on this, in terms of trying to study family factors to learn why parents take their child for conversion therapy and how we might work with parents and guardians around this issue," he said. "The second, from a policy perspective, is to get more states to make it explicitly illegal to use conversion therapy on minors. The third is for clinicians and individuals who work with families to have a better grasp on why this is harmful."
Support and acceptance from family members is directly linked to greater self-esteem, fewer instances of substance abuse and lower rates of depression in LGBTQ adolescents, the report states. Conversely, young adults who experience family rejection have higher rates of depression, substance abuse, sexually risky behaviors and suicide attempts.
Sending your child to conversion therapy is, quite obviously, neither supportive nor accepting.
"Now we can communicate that message with the backing of scientific literature, as well as an official government document," Wolff said.
It can be tempting, he noted, to assume conversion therapy — indeed, rejection of LGBTQ adolescents in any form — is largely fading into the distance.
It's not.
"Much of society is more tolerant and affirming," he said. "But that is not true in every part of this country, and it's not true even in the more progressive parts of this country. Kids who are gender nonconforming are still targets for bullying and victimization, and their parents are often not on board with how they're expressing their gender or sexuality.
"That can really catch kids off guard," he said, "when they expect their peers and family to be accepting and they get active rejection or bullying instead."
Maybe this report will be another step away from such madness.
